bibl.title: Letter from W.E. Safford to Henry Rose Carter, April 24, 1923

div1.p: Safford describes his work and theories on the origins of cultivated plants. He believes that the banana is of Old World origin.

div1.head: Letter from W.E. Safford to Henry Rose Carter, April 24, 1923
div1.opener:
Book
Stegomyia
(Safford)
ECONOMIC AND SYSTEMATIC BOTANY
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
BUREAU OF PLANT INDUSTRY
WASHINGTON
April 24, 1923.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
In reply to your inquiry, which reached me this morning, I
hasten to say that I must have been very misleading, if I gave you the
impression that I believed the banana to be a native of America. It is
undoubtedly of Old World origin. It was brought by the Polynesians with
them and had become spread among the islands of the Pacific before the
time of Magellan, but from the definite testimony of the most reliable
early writers it was introduced into America after the discovery.

Mr. O. F. Cock, of the Department of Agriculture, is one of my
best friends, yet I differ from him on several of his theories, especially
with many things he said in his article “The American Origin of Agriculture,”
first published in the Popular Science Monthly, October 1902. In that
paper he included bananas among the food plants which existed in America
before the arrival of the Spaniards (loc. cit. p. 495). In Contributions
from the United States National Herbarium, vol. 7, 1901, he declared
the coconut palm to be of American origin and added (p. 258) that “the
evidence of the existence of the banana in prehistoric America is equal, if
not superior, to that here presented for the coconut.”

In my work on the Useful Plants of the Island of Guam, published
as vol. 9 of Contributions from the United States National Herbarium, p.
328. 1905, I speak of the cultivation of the banana on the Island of Guam
in prehistoric times, and give its vernacular names in various eastern
localities. I remember talking with Mr. Cook about the origin of the banana
and asking him what tangible evidence he could cite to show the pre-
Columbian existence of the banana in America. He referred to some explorer
in Peru, who had found a leaf believed to be a banana leaf in a prehistoric
grave. I replied that I had assisted in the opening of about two hundred
graves in Peru, all of which contained vestiges of edible plants and some
of them representations of fruits, edible roots, etc., in terracotta
funeral vases, and among all of my material and the material obtained by
other explorers, there was not a vestige of a banana fruit, or leaf; al-
though some one had mistaken the terracotta representation of a manioc stem
with a cluster of roots hanging to it for a bunch of bananas.

Afterwards Mr. Cook, in Contributions from the United States National
Herbarium, vol. 14, part 2, 1910, states definitely that the banana is a na-
tive of the eastern continent (p.341): and in speaking of the introduction
of Old World plants into America (p. 274) he says: “The only tropical
types introduced during the period of the early discoveries appear to have
been the varieties of bananas and sugar-cane brought gver from the Canary
Islands.

I am sending you herewith a paper which I read before the First Pan
Pacific Scientific Conference, held at Honolulu in the summer of 1920, and
published in part 1, p. 183, of the Proceedings. 1921. This will show
-3-
the identity of the names of many of the food plants in various island
groups, and also of the Malayan origin of the plants and their names,
as well as of the Polynesians, which brought them from the cradle of
their race, in the Malay Archipelago.

An earlier paper of mine, read before the Nineteenth International
Congress of Americanists, was entitled Food-plants and Textiles of Ancient
America. This paper, based upon my material from prehistoric Peruvian
graves, was published in the Proceedings of that Congress pp. 12 ff. 1917;
also (with fewer illustrations) in the Proceedings of the Second Pan
American Scientific Congress, vol. 1, p. 146, ff. 1917.

In a recent paper, read last Summer at Rio Janeiro, on The Isolation of
Ancient America and the Antiquity of its Colonization Established by the
Food Plants of its Inhabitants, I contrast the conditions on this continent
with those of Polynesia. While the principal economic plants of the
Primitive Polynesians were of Asiatic origin and had undoubtedly accompanied
the Polynesians on their migrations from their cradle in the Malay Archipelago,
every cultivated plant encountered by Columbus and those who followed him to
the New World, in both North and South America, and in the islands where
they first landed, was absolutely unknown to the inhabitants of the Old World.
In other words, not a single cereal, vegetable, fruit, or edible root of Europe,
Asia, or Africa, had found its way to the Western Hemisphere before the time
of Columbus; nor had a grain of maize, common beans or Lima beans, potato or
sweet potato, or any other plant indigenous to the New World reached the Old
World. Thousands and thousands of years must have been necessary to produce
maize in all its varieties and spread it over North and South America into
-4-
localities characterized by widely different conditions of soil and climate.
And the same is true of beans, squashes, and other food staples widely
spread in prehistoric times; as well as of the various species of tobacco.
Once discovered it is remarkable how rapidly many of these plants spread
to the remotest corners of the earth.

But I will refrain. I expect some day to publish my paper, and
will be glad to send you a reprint of it should you care for one.

I am very glad to know you are interested in the origin of culti-
vated plants. I hope some day to do a great work bearing upon this subject.
div1.closer:
Believe me, ever faithfully yours, W. E. Safford
Economic Botanist. WES/EBH
